content:
Key Points

  • Real estate negotiations make or break your client’s deal – and your reputation.
  • Great negotiation = more referrals, more commission, less chaos.
  • Know your local market cold to strengthen your offers and counters.
  • Agents must set goals and prep clients before any negotiating begins.
  • Push, pull, persist: negotiation is about adapting, not dominating.
  • Master communication: ask questions, shut up, and listen.
  • Timing can change everything – use it to your advantage.
  • Use data, not drama, to support your position.
  • Face-to-face still beats flashy tech in high-stakes negotiations.
  • Smart Agent Alliance gives agents the tools, training, and support to win.

Ah, real estate negotiations – where your commission, your sanity, and your client’s blood pressure all hang in the balance. One wrong move, and it’s not just a lost deal… it’s a client muttering your name during therapy. Whether you’re a new real estate agent still wondering how do real estate agents negotiate or a certified real estate negotiator who’s been through enough counteroffers to develop a permanent eye twitch, one thing’s true: negotiation isn’t a skill – it’s survival.

You don’t need to be a Jedi or a mind reader. But you do need to know how to control the room, keep your client calm, and still land a deal that doesn’t make everyone want to retire early. Ready to boost your real estate agent negotiation skills and stop treating every conversation like a coin toss?

Understanding Real Estate Negotiation
Building Rapport and Trust
Frequently Asked Questions

Understanding Real Estate Negotiation

What Is Real Estate Negotiation?

Real estate negotiation is a back-and-forth discussion in which buyers and sellers negotiate their needs and make an agreement that works for both parties. At its essence, it’s about identifying the intersection of shared interests that provides value for everyone involved.

This process protects and helps both buyers and sellers. It enables them to negotiate on important items like price, closing costs, and repairs in good faith. In real estate, negotiations typically begin with an opener and proceed through stages, including counteroffers, before agreeing to terms.

Meeting in person or talking over the phone can be critical when working out the details.

Why Negotiation Skills Matter

It’s why fierce negotiation skills are at the very core of winning clients the best possible deals. Good negotiators are mediators, able to diffuse tension and conflict by uncovering common ground and mutually beneficial solutions.

They maintain a crucial advantage in the cutthroat commercial and residential real estate market, continuing to steer clear of fads and advisor disintermediation in a hyper-transactional marketplace. Rejecting a proposal doesn’t mean the end – doing so often just creates room for more negotiation and revision.

Key Elements of Successful Negotiation

Key ingredients such as preparation, effective communication, and knowing what interests are at stake make for the best negotiations. Flexibility and creativity go a long way in overcoming hurdles, making sure these solutions work for all parties involved.

Second, a win-win mindset is essential, building deeper relationships and enabling better transactions.

Use Networking to Improve Your Information Gathering and Negotiation Strategy

Networking is an excellent tool with which to gather information.

Preparing for Negotiations

Know Your Local Market

Researching the local market is essential to crafting winning negotiation tactics. Smart real estate agents will look at the trends in their market and make smart decisions on the price points. This includes comparing the property with similar properties to determine a competitive asking price.

For example, information about the sale price of other nearby homes with similar attributes can give you bargaining power during negotiations. Knowing your neighborhood’s dynamics, such as what developments are coming in, or what your school district’s rating is, makes your case much stronger.  Not sure where to start?  Check out your local MLS for stats or use RPR, Research tab, Residential Market Trends

Conduct Thorough Research

In short, diligent research is the key to winning negotiations. By examining buyer demographics and preferences, real estate agents can adapt their strategies to align with what buyers are looking for.

Researching comparable sales and current market conditions can provide a picture of the most effective approach to negotiation. In addition, putting together a list of potential buyer issues – like its condition or what amenities your community has – lets agents respond to objections before they’re raised.

Define Clear Goals

Clearly defined, measurable goals are key to informing your negotiation priorities and discussions. Agents need to focus on these client objectives, getting to the heart of what is most important to the client.

Being clear about these goals with everyone involved from the get-go helps avoid mismatched expectations or other confusion down the road.

Essential Strategies for Effective Negotiation

Navigating real estate negotiations requires developing strategies that best serve client interests while adapting to competitive conditions. It’s less about having a rigid negotiation strategy, more about having a flexible plan that can adapt on the fly to the buyer’s reaction to the plan.

Develop a culture of collaboration and partnership to empower honest conversation and joint problem-solving. This is a great first step in changing the narrative from a zero-sum game to a more collaborative win-win.

1. Master the Push, Pull, Persist Technique

The push, pull, persist approach is especially important in tough situations. This means presenting offers fairly but assertively, typically influenced by the first anchor offer, but still allowing for buyer counteroffer input.

Persisting keeps the conversation going even when there is pushback and allows negotiations to continue to be fruitful.

2. Set Realistic Expectations

Establishing realistic expectations around price and terms is key. By educating clients on the current state of the market, you can set the right expectations and avoid disappointment.

This approach also helps in developing patience and understanding during negotiations.

3. Manage Emotions and Stay Positive

Arriving with a cool head makes for a constructive atmosphere. Identifying emotional triggers and defusing them with positive language and body language helps establish and maintain a positive environment.

4. Base Decisions on Market Value

Providing valid market data to defend offers and counteroffers sets a fair price for negotiation. Analyzing like-kind properties and using those findings to inform negotiations strengthens negotiation positions.

This practice makes for stronger arguments during discussions.

5. Be Ready to Walk Away

Set client expectations around what it may mean to walk away from the deal if negotiations do not go as planned. By focusing on a strong BATNA, you increase your confidence in the deal and leverage your willingness to walk away.

Techniques for Successful Communication

This is crucial in real estate negotiations. By listening to understand instead of reacting, we can learn what people really need and how we can best help them.

Clarity: Articulating thoughts clearly helps prevent misunderstandings, ensuring all parties are on the same page. These prompt deeper conversations and help agents peel back the layers of why a client is motivated and identify concerns below the surface.

Engage in Direct Conversations

Direct, honest dialogue reduces the risk of misinterpretation. There’s no substitute for the rapport built through face-to-face meetings, which help foster trust.

Use Questions Effectively

Opening with strategic questioning can help you uncover what is important to the buyer. By guiding conversations with open-ended questions, we arrive at collaborative, win-win solutions. Encourage questions so that clients can assure themselves that they understand.

Prefer Face-to-Face Communication

Face-to-face conversations are essential for developing trust. Agents should focus here first instead of spending a ton of time and money on digital strategies. Non-verbal communication provides a wealth of information in the negotiating process.

Arm Yourself With Data

Building argumentation positions with data is critical. Proven data and market research add credibility to your claims. Credibility rests on the issue of whether you’re presenting current information.

Leveraging Timing and Offers

Timing is everything in real estate negotiations. When you know how the timing of your offers influences the course of negotiations, you give yourself an incredible advantage.

Here’s a markdown table to illustrate the impact:

Leverage Timing for Advantage

Negotiating with the right timing in mind can produce a sense of urgency. Reverse timing your negotiation for the end of the fiscal quarter can play to your benefit. For many landlords, the mad dash to close deals starts this time of year.

Keeping an eye on market conditions helps you figure out the best times to make offers, matching buyer sentiment and market fluctuations. For example, winter is typically a slower time for the housing market, which means more favorable offers might be within reach.

Understanding when these ups and downs happen puts you in the position to strike with laser-like focus.

Offer Multiple Choices

Providing more than one option increases decision-maker engagement and negotiation readiness. This method protects buyers’ needs and powers, while steering them toward the outcomes you want most.

Showing the advantages of each choice makes it easier to compare and choose one. Showing alternative pricing models or payment plans can lure in prospective buyers.

It makes them feel powerful, while at the same time leading them to a more favorable decision.

Use Escalation Clauses Effectively

Escalation clauses are one way to make offers stronger – particularly in competitive situations. By structuring them smartly, you can protect your clients’ interests while signaling your good faith.

These escalation clauses instantly ramp up your offer when faced with higher competing bids, showing you mean business. Even just setting a cap is a big first step to getting in control of your boundaries.

That’s how you win the date and keep the client’s budget healthy.

Building Rapport and Trust

Building rapport and trust with clients goes a long way in making successful real estate negotiations. Here’s a few ways to get started:

  • Pay attention to what clients say and reflect back.
  • Empathy: Show understanding and share in their feelings.
  • Personalized Communication: Tailor messages to make clients feel special.

Talk about non-work things to build rapport and trust. Make notes for birthdays, hobbies, family members, etc. By investing time in understanding clients’ needs and preferences, agents can demonstrate clients are valued and respected.

Casual chitchat prior to negotiating helps set a good mood, creating an environment where strong rapport can lead to better outcomes.

Foster Goodwill Through Reciprocity

Creating goodwill is another way to build trust. Providing concessions to counterparts can lead to greater collaboration and a continued spirit of cooperation. Experienced Fredericksburg realtors can best guide you through which concessions are fair and what they should look like given market trends and the condition of the property.

Small acts of goodwill – an understanding with regards to timelines or fixing small repairs – can go a long way toward winning a buyer’s favor. This strategy underscores the value of reciprocity in negotiations and aids in building relationships that last well past the present transaction.

Encourage Agreement as Their Idea

Making sure clients feel a sense of ownership over agreements will help boost their level of commitment. It is often possible to maneuver discussions to get clients to view settlements as their own solutions.

Persuasive techniques that frame recommendations the right way can help deepen client engagement. Beyond fortifying the negotiation process, this tactic cultivates satisfaction with results.

By empowering the client to be the decision-maker, agents will set themselves up for better negotiations and more robust client relationships.

Maintain Transparency and Ethical Practices

First and foremost, transparency and honesty are key from start to finish during the negotiation process. Help clients avoid distractions, keep their eye on the financial prize, and always keep communication lines open. Offer impartial advice that keeps emotion from influencing important decisions. This level of consistent engagement helps make sure everyone is on the same page about the details, minimizing the chance for last-minute surprises.

Managing Offers and Counteroffers

Smartly managing offers and counteroffers is one of the most important parts of successful real estate negotiations. Best practices are to avoid surprises, be honest about limitations, and know the power of a personal touch.

Acting quickly on received offers prevents losing momentum, meaning everyone involved stays excited and eager to move forward.

  • Respond quickly to maintain interest.
  • Be clear and transparent about constraints.
  • Use structured frameworks for clarity.
  • Prioritize face-to-face interactions when possible.
  • Follow up verbal discussions with formal offers.

Present Offers in Person

Delivering offers in person conveys a sense of sincerity and seriousness. Most importantly, it allows you to address concerns on the spot, which makes the negotiation feel more personal.

This strategy builds mutual trust, which is crucial in any deep-dive transaction.

Discuss by Phone First

These early phone conversations can help lay the groundwork for formal offers to come. They provide a way to hash out details and build rapport, making the jump to written communication much smoother.

Putting it all down in writing with a formal offer goes a long way in memorializing the deal.

Use a Framework for Your Negotiation

A clear framework provides a roadmap for tough conversations, helping to keep negotiations on track. Important details, such as goals and timelines, as well as communication standards, keep everyone on track and working toward the same goal.

It’s a big help in setting appropriate financial limits and bottom lines, which is key when you find yourself in a multiple offer scenario.

Advanced Negotiation Tactics

Mastering advanced real estate negotiation tactics is key. Here are some advanced tactics to enhance your negotiation prowess:

  • Set a strong initial offer to anchor the discussion.
  • Reflect the other party’s language and behavior to build rapport.
  • Use silence to prompt the other party to fill the gap.
  • Bundling: Combine offers to create value for both parties.
  • BATNA: Know your Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement.

These strategies allow you to develop a negotiation approach that is fluid and flexible. You can also boost your negotiation prowess by taking the Certified Real Estate Negotiator (CREN) course, the Real Estate Negotiation Expert (RENE) certification or the OnlineEd’s Negotiation skills training.

Control Your Emotions

In high-stakes negotiations, staying calm under fire is key. When emotions take over rational thought, we tend to get the short end of the stick.

By intentionally practicing mindfulness and reducing stress, you open yourself up to making better decisions without confusion or miscommunication.

Exhibit Patience and Determination

Key Points

  • Repurposing saves agents from constant content burnout.
  • One blog can become 10+ pieces across platforms.
  • Evergreen posts are goldmines for repurposing.
  • Use feedback and metrics to choose what to repurpose.
  • Tools like Canva and Vidyo simplify repurposing workflows.
  • Repurposing content = less stress, more ROI.
  • Smart Agent Alliance gives agents tools to work smarter.

Ever feel like you’re stuck on the content hamster wheel – posting on social, writing blogs, filming videos – only to watch your “engagement” trickle in like a leaky faucet? Yeah, same. Welcome to the never-ending hustle of trying to stay visible without losing your mind or your weekends.

Here’s the truth: most agents don’t need more content. They need to repurpose content they already have. We’re talking about turning that once-forgotten blog post into a podcast, that listing video into five Reels, and those half-dead captions into actual lead magnets.

It’s not just time-saving – it’s sanity-saving. And the benefits of repurposing content go beyond eyeballs. It’s how you grow your brand without burning out, reach new people across platforms, and keep showing up everywhere… even when you’re just showing up to Starbucks.

Here’s your handy-dandy index:

What Is Content Repurposing
Benefits of Repurposing Content

How to Identify Content for Repurposing

Strategies for Repurposing Written Content

Techniques for Repurposing Video Content

Approaches for Repurposing Social Media Content

Methods for Repurposing Newsletter Content

Tools to Simplify Content Repurposing

Best Practices for Effective Repurposing

Repurposing is the Smart Way
Frequently Asked Questions

What Is Content Repurposing

Content repurposing is about transforming your existing content into new formats to reach a wider audience. This strategy saves time, reduces burnout, and keeps your content fresh and engaging.

Repurposing also reinforces your brand voice, ensuring consistency across platforms. It’s also an SEO powerhouse – embedding visuals like infographics or videos boosts engagement, shares, and rankings. Repurposing content makes your work do more for you.

Benefits of Repurposing Content

Save Time and Energy

Why start from scratch when you can build on what already works? It’s a pressure reliever for content creators, freeing them to focus on quality instead of constantly brainstorming new ideas.

Reach More People

When you repurpose content, you open doors to audiences you might not be reaching. By tailoring formats to audience preferences, you expand your reach. Pair this with analytics and influencer amplification, and your content gets the spotlight it deserves.

Maximize ROI

Repurpose content and you boost the value of your best content. Use audience feedback and metrics to find winners and adapt them to fresh formats. It’s all about making every piece of content work harder and last longer.

Boost Engagement

Different formats attract different audiences. A detailed case study may captivate industry pros, while a snappy explainer video appeals to younger viewers.

How to Identify Content for Repurposing

Choose Evergreen Winners

Evergreen content is the backbone of repurposing. Think timeless topics like “how-to” guides or industry insights that stay relevant year after year. A post on time management tips, for example, could be refreshed annually with updated examples. Skip outdated, hyper-specific pieces – like a blog tied to a 2024 event -unless you can adapt them to today’s trends.

Even older content can shine again with some tweaking. Refresh pre-pandemic posts to make them post-pandemic relevant or repurpose topics like “remote work best practices” to align with today’s hybrid work environment. Evergreen content grows stronger with updates, giving it an extended shelf life and new appeal.

Spot High Performers

Your most engaging content is gold for repurposing. Use metrics like page views, social shares, and comments to pinpoint what resonates most. Aim to get at least five new pieces from one standout post to maximize its impact.

Focus on What’s Relevant

Staying relevant means knowing what your audience needs now. Revamp older posts to match current trends. Tie repurposed content into your upcoming campaigns, using it as a bridge to highlight your solutions.

Strategies for Repurposing Written Content

Turn Blogs into Social Media Posts

Your blogs are packed with content perfect for social media. Extract key insights or stats, pair them with eye-catching graphics, and you’ve got engaging posts. A single blog could yield at least five mini posts – an intro, a highlight of the main takeaway, a quote graphic, and more. For instance, if your blog goes live on Friday, use the following week to break it into smaller, focused posts for different platforms.

Transform Blogs into Infographics

Infographics are a fantastic way to simplify complex topics. Pull out key data or concepts from your blog and collaborate with a designer to create visuals that captivate. Share these visuals on platforms like Pinterest, LinkedIn, or X to reach more visual learners. Track metrics like shares and clicks to measure impact and refine future infographics.

Rework Blogs into Email Newsletters

Blogs can supercharge your email campaigns. Break down posts into short, actionable tips, like turning a home buyer guide blog into a “3 Quick Tips” email segment. Personalize emails by segmenting your audience based on interests or behavior, making content feel targeted and relevant.

Create Videos from Blog Insights

Videos can make your blog content pop. Draft a quick outline or script from your blog and use tools like screen recording software to produce engaging videos. For instance, a blog on “AI in Real Estate” could become a YouTube video, Instagram Reel, or TikTok clip.

Use Blog Snippets for Community Discussions

Short snippets from your blogs can spark meaningful conversations. Share quotes or thought-provoking questions in forums like LinkedIn groups or Reddit. For example, a blog on AI and real estate might inspire a question like, “How do you see AI shaping the future of real estate?”

Techniques for Repurposing Video Content

Break Long Videos into Short Clips

Long videos are treasure troves of bite-sized gems that can shine as standalone content. Pull out the most impactful moments – memorable quotes, surprising facts, or actionable tips – and create short clips tailored for platforms like Instagram Reels, TikTok, or YouTube Shorts. Adding captions ensures accessibility, while hashtags boost discoverability.

Turn Video Content into Interactive Slideshows

Transform videos into engaging slideshows or carousel posts for platforms like LinkedIn or Instagram. Extract the key points from your video and design them as visually appealing slides with concise takeaways. This is a great way to repurpose content for users who prefer skimming through visuals instead of watching full videos. Tools like Canva or Google Slides can streamline this process, making it quick and professional.

Extract Key Points for Blog Posts

Videos packed with educational value can easily translate into blog posts. Pull the main lessons or insights and use screenshots or stills from the video to enhance the post visually. This not only creates additional content but also provides a clickable link back to the original video, driving traffic between platforms.

Convert Videos into Podcasts

Many audiences prefer to listen rather than watch, making podcasts a perfect way to repurpose video content. Strip the audio from interviews, tutorials, or panel discussions, clean it up, and add polished intros or transitions. Podcasts are especially effective for long-form discussions and can reach new listeners when distributed on platforms like Spotify or Apple Podcasts.

Use Video Stills for Visual Posts

Screenshots from your videos can become eye-catching social media posts. Capture impactful moments – whether it’s a quote, stat, or emotional reaction – and pair them with text overlays or calls to action. These stills are perfect for Instagram, Pinterest, or even as thumbnails for emails, driving engagement with minimal effort.

Compile Highlights into Recap Videos

At the end of a month or campaign, pull highlights from multiple videos to create a recap reel. This can serve as a summary for your audience and to showcase your best content. Share these compilations on social media or email newsletters to re-engage your audience and remind them of the value you provide.

Approaches for Repurposing Social Media Content

Turn Stories into Highlight Reels

Social media stories are often short-lived but packed with engaging content. Repurpose the best moments into highlight reels for platforms like Instagram, Facebook, or YouTube. Combine a week’s worth of tips, behind-the-scenes footage, or FAQs into a cohesive reel that gives new life to your disappearing content. These highlights serve as evergreen resources for your audience and continue to attract engagement long after the original story expires.

Expand Comments into FAQs

Social media comments are a goldmine of audience questions and feedback. Compile the most common or insightful comments and turn them into an FAQ section for your website or a standalone blog post. For instance, questions from a popular Instagram Q&A can evolve into a detailed guide or explainer video. This not only addresses audience curiosity but also reinforces your position as an expert in your niche.

Repurpose Polls into Infographics

Poll results on platforms like Instagram Stories or LinkedIn can be transformed into visually engaging infographics. Take the percentages or insights from your audience votes and present them in an appealing, shareable format. Pair these infographics with your interpretation of the results, turning simple polls into valuable data-driven content for blogs or newsletters.

Cluster Posts into Ebooks

Collect similar posts, like a series of tips or advice shared over time, and bundle them into a downloadable ebook. For instance, a set of LinkedIn posts on marketing strategies can be expanded with examples and additional insights to create a comprehensive resource. Offer this ebook as a lead magnet to grow your email list while repurposing content you’ve already created.

Transform Live Content into Snippets

If you’ve hosted a live stream on Instagram, TikTok, or Facebook, there’s no reason to let it fade into the void. Clip key moments from the session, such as tips, audience questions, or insightful discussions, and share them as standalone videos. These snippets are ideal for social posts or as teasers to promote the replay of the full session.

Repurpose DMs into Personal Stories

Direct messages often include testimonials, questions, or feedback that can be repurposed (anonymously if needed) into compelling personal stories. Share these as part of your posts or emails to add a relatable, human touch to your content while showcasing your impact on your audience.

Methods for Repurposing Newsletter Content

Share Snippets as Social Media Posts

Your newsletter is packed with bite-sized wisdom perfect for social media. Pull out key quotes, insights, or stats and turn them into short, engaging updates. For example, a thought-provoking sentence from your newsletter could spark a X thread or a LinkedIn post that drives meaningful discussions.

Turn Data into Eye-Catching Visuals

Newsletters often include data and statistics that can shine as infographics or graphics. Transform those figures into visually compelling content for platforms like Instagram or Pinterest. For example, a percentage shared in your newsletter could become a colorful graphic, making complex information easier to understand.

Condense Insights into Short Videos

Short-form videos are king across social media. Break down sections of your newsletter into quick, dynamic clips to share on platforms like TikTok, Instagram Reels, or YouTube Shorts. Highlight key takeaways with visually appealing edits using tools like Canva or Adobe Express (used to be Adobe Spark).

Compile Themes into Blog Posts

If your newsletter follows recurring themes, compile related content into a comprehensive blog post. For example, a series of newsletters on market trends could become an in-depth article analyzing shifts over the past quarter.

Tools to Simplify Content Repurposing

Video Editing Made Easy

Repurposing video content is a breeze with tools like Vidyo and Adobe Premiere Rush. These user-friendly platforms let you trim long-form videos into short, shareable clips perfect for TikTok or Instagram Reels. Features like built-in templates and quick color corrections save time while keeping your content polished. For example, a 30-minute podcast can easily yield several impactful snippets.

Leverage online tutorials to get the most out of these tools and boost team collaboration. Once your clips are live, track engagement metrics like views and shares to see what resonates. This ensures your efforts focus on creating content your audience loves.

Graphic Design for Everyone

Creating stunning visuals is effortless with tools like Canva and Adobe Express. These platforms offer drag-and-drop simplicity and customizable templates, allowing you to transform a blog header or infographic into formats tailored for Instagram, Pinterest, or email headers. Adjust fonts, colors, and layouts to stay on brand while delivering eye-catching designs.

By tracking performance metrics such as click-through rates, you can refine your designs to maximize impact. For instance, if a graphic showcasing real estate tips performs well, replicate its style across other content to maintain consistency and engagement.

Streamlined Social Media

Once your content is ready, tools like Buffer and Hootsuite make scheduling and posting a seamless process. Automate your posts across platforms to maintain a consistent schedule and free up your time. Performance dashboards help you identify what content works best, informing future

Best Practices for Effective Repurposing

Set Clear Guidelines

Start with a content brief to identify repurposing opportunities, like turning blogs into podcasts or social posts. Use a style guide to ensure tone, visuals, and messaging are consistent across all formats. Updating older content with current trends keeps it relevant and engaging.

Track What Works

Use analytics to measure KPIs like engagement and conversions. Monitor what formats perform best on each platform and refine your strategy based on data, ensuring each piece resonates with your audience.

Tailor for Platforms

Customize content for specific platforms. Instagram thrives on visuals, LinkedIn needs in-depth posts, and Twitter excels with concise threads. Adapting content boosts engagement and ensures it fits the audience’s preferences.

Stay Consistent

Consistency builds trust. Follow brand guidelines for tone, visuals, and messaging. Use audience feedback to refine your approach and ensure your brand identity shines across all platforms, from professional LinkedIn posts to creative Instagram visuals.

Repurposing is the Smart Way

Repurposing content is a game-changing strategy that allows you to maximize your efforts, reach new audiences, and keep your content fresh across platforms. Embrace these methods to work smarter, not harder, and keep your audience engaged wherever they are. For more smart ideas, check out our marketing blogs for real estate agents.

content:
Key Points

  • Most agents don’t need more leads – they need the right ones
  • Buyer personas and niche marketing bring stronger results
  • Local SEO and smart ads drive high-intent traffic
  • High-value content builds trust and captures leads
  • Video and social media increase engagement and conversions
  • Print, events, and open houses still work when done right
  • Fast, automated follow-up turns leads into appointments
  • Referral networks and CRM tools boost buyer pipeline
  • Incentives and buyer education improve conversion rates

If you’re tired of chasing ghost leads, talking to “just browsing” buyers, or refreshing your inbox like it owes you a closing – welcome. Most agents don’t struggle with finding people. They struggle with finding the right people. The ones who are ready to act, not just ask a thousand questions and disappear when it’s time to sign.

Want to learn how to find buyers in real estate who are actually serious? You don’t need gimmicks. You need a system. This guide walks you through exactly how top agents attract, connect with, and convert motivated buyers using a combo of smart targeting, modern marketing, and buyer psychology that doesn’t suck your soul dry.

Here’s your handy-dandy index:

Define and Target Your Ideal Buyers

Attract Buyers Online

Content That Converts Buyers

Offline Tactics That Still Work

Automated Follow-Up That Feels Personal

Real Relationships = Referral Machines

Advanced Buyer Conversion Techniques

Finding Real Buyers Isn’t Magic – It’s Method
Frequently Asked Questions

Define and Target Your Ideal Buyers

Start With Buyer Personas

Before you post another ad or build a landing page, stop. Who are you even trying to reach? Creating solid buyer personas means less random effort and more intentional results. For a step-by-step guide on developing real estate buyer personas, check out this resource from Milesbrand. Are you working with first-time buyers, move-up families, investors, or downsizers? You need to know their motivations, fears, timelines, and budgets like the back of your CRM.

Skip the surface stuff. Your personas should include:

  • Price range and preferred neighborhoods
  • Financing knowledge (or lack thereof)
  • Lifestyle goals (schools, walkability, fixer-uppers vs. turnkeys)
  • Dealbreakers and wishlist items

The better your buyer profiles, the easier it is to speak their language – and show up in their world before another agent does. Pro tip: If you don’t know how to get started on this task, open up ChatGPT and ask for it.

Tap Into Niche Segments

Generalists get general results. Want more serious, ready-to-act leads? Niche down. Explore the most profitable real estate niches and why they work in this article by Luxury Presence. Focus on groups like:

  • Eco-conscious buyers who prioritize green features
  • Luxury buyers with specific neighborhood tastes
  • Renters transitioning to first-time ownership
  • Multigenerational buyers looking for space with flexibility

These buyers have hyper-specific needs – and when your marketing speaks directly to them, they’ll skip the “research phase” and head straight to “let’s chat.”

Attract Buyers Online

Nail Your Local SEO

Most buyers start their journey on Google – not by calling an agent. If your online presence isn’t showing up when they search “condos in Your City” or “best Your City neighborhoods for families,” you’re invisible.

Use real estate SEO strategies to show up where it counts. BrightLocal offers tailored local SEO strategies specifically for real estate professionals. Show up where it counts:

  • Add location-based keywords to your blog, bio, and service pages
  • Write neighborhood guides and community breakdowns
  • Create landing pages for specific buyer types (free landing pages offer here).

And yes – claim and optimize your Google Business Profile. It’s free, it works, and it boosts your visibility in local map results.

Do Smart Keyword Research

Let’s kill the guesswork. Tools like Ubersuggest, Google Keyword Planner, and SEMRush show you what your buyers are searching for right now. Target keyword phrases that match your buyer personas, like:

  • “Homes with in-law units in Mill Valley”
  • “Low HOA condos for sale Marin”
  • “Best places to buy a house near SF commute”

This isn’t keyword stuffing – it’s showing up where serious buyers are looking.

Advertise With Intention

Random Facebook ads? Waste of money. Strategic, targeted ad campaigns? Goldmine.
Use:

  • Google Ads to grab high-intent search traffic
  • Facebook & Instagram ads to retarget site visitors and promote listings
  • A/B testing to tweak creative, headlines, and CTAs

Track your results like a hawk. No more throwing money into the void.

Optimize Your Landing Pages

Clicking your ad shouldn’t lead to a generic homepage. Build dedicated landing pages for:

  • First-time buyer guides
  • Investment property searches
  • Schedule-a-tour CTAs
  • “Best neighborhoods” lead magnets

Make them fast, mobile-friendly, and conversion-focused – or your clicks will bounce harder than a rent check in escrow. If you join our sponsor team, Smart Agent Alliance, we provide 8 landing page templates with automated email drips to keep you top of mind. This is how to get buyers while you’re doing something else.

Content That Converts Buyers

Create High-Value, Searchable Content

Want to get buyers in real estate who are already half-sold? Be the one who answers their questions before they even ask. Start building trust (and your email list) with:

  • Blog posts like “What Does a Buyers Agent Do?” or “Top 5 Questions to Ask a Buyers Agent”
  • Downloadables: real estate checklists for buyers, mortgage prep guides, or neighborhood comparisons
  • Market updates or property tour roundups

Not only does this content position you as the go-to expert – it helps warm up cold leads without spending a dime on ads.

Use Video to Educate and Engage

Let’s be real – no one’s reading a 3-paragraph property description when they could watch a walkthrough instead. Video is your cheat code for both buyers agent presentations and building likeability fast.

Use it to:

  • Break down the buying process (“What to Expect at Your First Buyers Consultation”)
  • Bust common myths (“Do Buyers Pay Realtor Fees?”)
  • Offer sneak peeks of listings or community features

Keep videos short, vertical, and full of personality. Bonus points if you go live for local Q&As or virtual open houses – buyers engage more when it feels real

Go All-In on Social Media

Posting isn’t enough. You need to connect. Build an ongoing relationship with future buyers by mixing:

  • Buyer success stories (yes, even if it’s “we got their offer accepted with zero drama”)
  • Tips, FAQs, and behind-the-scenes from your day
  • Local happenings, market shifts, or even memes that tie into buying

Instagram, Facebook, YouTube Shorts – whatever platform matches your persona, show up there. Social is your digital handshake. Keep it active, authentic, and invite engagement (polls, DMs, comments). See how to get social media training valued at over $10,500 below.

Keep the Value Coming

Buyer leads don’t stay warm on their own. Keep adding value even after they’ve downloaded your guide or DM’d about a listing. That means:

  • Weekly emails with curated listings or local intel
  • Invitations to webinars or workshops
  • Friendly check-ins if they ghosted last week’s showing invite

Be the agent who shows up with helpful stuff, not the one who only texts “still looking?” every three months.

Offline Tactics That Still Work

Use Print and Direct Mail With a Purpose

Yes, print still works – when you’re not mailing stuff that looks like it came from a 1998 Microsoft Publisher template. Even the National Association of REALTORS® still discusses the effectiveness of direct mail in real estate marketing. Create sleek, modern postcards or brochures that offer real value:

  • Market stats
  • Local inventory snapshots
  • Neighborhood spotlights
  • Invitations to buyer events

Include QR codes that link to your real estate buyers presentation or landing page. Then track responses and follow up like you actually want the client.

Host Open Houses Like a Lead Magnet

Stop treating open houses like passive weekend duty. These are IRL funnels – especially for buyers who haven’t picked their agent yet.

Treat them like mini-events:

  • Use sign-in apps to instantly drop visitors into your follow-up sequence
  • Invite local lenders to co-host (they love exposure)
  • Offer buyer resource sheets or exclusive previews

And, don’t miss top tips for successful open houses along with our free open house sheets.

Run Smart Local Events

Skip the basic happy hour. Run workshops that actually solve problems for your ideal buyers:

  • “First-Time Buyer Bootcamp”
  • “Buy vs. Rent in Today’s Market”
  • “How to Buy and Sell at the Same Time”

Partner with mortgage pros, title reps, or home inspectors. They get visibility, you get leads, and your attendees get answers. (Plus, it’s easier to schedule a buyers consultation when someone already met you at your event.)

Turn Sellers Into Buyers

Don’t forget – every seller needs to buy next. Offer a free pricing consultation that includes both a listing analysis and a buyer plan for their next move.

Follow up post-sale with helpful nudges about new listings in their price range, or connections to agents in their destination city if they’re moving out of area. Be the full-service buyers agent they didn’t know they needed.

Automated Follow-Up That Feels Personal

Use SMS and Email to Stay Top of Mind

Buyers today expect fast responses. And no, your once-a-month newsletter doesn’t count. To stay in the game, your follow-up needs to be fast, personal, and tailored.

Here’s how to keep buyers warm:

  • SMS: Great for instant reminders – open houses, price drops, or new listing alerts. Keep it short, sweet, and opt-in only.
  • Email: Segment by buyer type. First-time buyer? Send them a financing prep checklist. Luxury relocation client? Hit them with market data and off-market access.

The more relevant your content, the less likely it ends up in their trash folder.

Automate Like a Human (Not a Robot)

CRMs like Boldtrail, Follow Up Boss, or Chime can automate the grunt work without making you sound like a chatbot from 2009.

Set up:

  • Action-triggered emails (clicked a listing = “Want a tour?”)
  • Follow-up texts after form fills or downloads
  • Reminder sequences for your buyers consultation real estate appointments

Use merge tags to personalize messages and keep the tone casual – like you’re texting a friend, not selling them a timeshare.

Add Value on Autopilot

Your CRM shouldn’t just drip content. It should drip value. Build sequences that deliver:

  • Your real estate agent checklist for buyers
  • Video intros on what to expect from a buyer’s agent
  • Market watch reports or inventory snapshots

Most agents automate once and forget it. Great agents check performance monthly and adjust. You’re not a spammer. You’re their go-to guide through the chaos.

Real Relationships = Referral Machines

Build a Referral Network of Real Estate Pros

You know who talks to buyers before they even look at homes? Lenders. Inspectors. CPAs. Divorce attorneys. Make friends with these folks.

Get intentional:

  • Book 1-on-1 coffees
  • Trade referrals and follow up when they convert
  • Share each other’s content or co-host events

When they know your buyers consultation is smooth, informative, and not pushy, they’ll keep sending clients your way.

Treat Past Clients Like Future Clients

The deal closing isn’t the end – it’s the prequel. Stay in touch with past buyers by offering:

  • Annual home value updates
  • Market trend insights
  • Local events or homeowner checklists

Ask for reviews after you’ve done something helpful (like sending a reminder to file for their tax exemption). When you keep delivering, asking for a referral becomes a no-brainer.

Always Ask the Right Questions

Building real relationships means more than just saying “let me know if you need anything.” Use every buyer interaction – especially the buyers consultation – to uncover what matters.

Ask:

content:
Key Points

  • Listings bring leverage – buyers bring burnout. Focus on where the control is.
  • Use cash offer programs to start seller conversations fast.
  • Ditch Zestimates. Offer detailed home valuations with real market insight.
  • FSBOs and expireds aren’t cold leads – they’re unfinished business.
  • Farming still works – when you show up like a brand, not a billboard.
  • Client referrals don’t happen unless you give them a reason to refer you.
  • Divorce attorneys, local events, and small businesses = secret seller pipelines.
  • Social media done right is a modern-day listing machine.

If you’ve ever cried in your car after another buyer ghosted you post-showing, welcome. This one’s for you.

Because no matter how many times the industry changes or the NAR rewrites the rules, one thing hasn’t changed: listings = leverage. Listing agents still get more control, less chaos, and let’s be real, less time chasing texts that start with “we’ve decided to wait.”

Yes, being a listing agent costs more upfront – photos, marketing, staging – but you’re also not spending your weekends unlocking doors for people whose “budget” is a Pinterest board and a dream. With the shift in buyer agent compensation (thanks NAR!), more buyers than ever are skipping agents altogether, but sellers? Sellers still need you. Badly. Especially if they want to avoid turning their property into a Zillow punchline.

So let’s get serious about how to get listings as a real estate agent, even if you’re new, rebuilding, or just tired of crossing your fingers at open houses. Here’s your handy-dandy index:

Understand the Market First
Frequently Asked Questions

Understand the Market First

If you’re serious about figuring out how to get listings as a real estate agent, you need more than a surface-level market update. Sellers don’t want a weather report – they want you to tell them whether it’s raining inside their zip code. So before you even think about sending another “Just Listed” postcard, do the homework.

Start with the Big Picture (a.k.a. Why Your Sellers Are Freaked Out)

You need to know what the national and regional housing trends are doing so you can sound like a pro – not someone who Googled “housing update” five minutes before a listing appointment.

Interest rates. Inflation. Inventory shifts. These aren’t just headlines – they’re the reason your seller’s neighbor’s house sat for 93 days or why bidding wars went MIA in your town. Show your clients how the macro trends trickle down into their backyard. Literally.

Demographic changes also matter. Are retirees moving in? Are millennials cashing out of downtown shoeboxes for suburban space? Understanding who’s coming and going helps you identify which homes are likely to list next – and what kinds of features will actually sell.

Then Zoom in Like You’ve Got a Microscope on Their Block

This is where you dominate – if you do it right. If you want to be the agent who lands more real estate listings, this is where you ditch the cookie-cutter comps pitch and show them what really sells.

Here’s what you need to do (no, really):

  • Walk every comparable like a detective, because photos won’t tell you if the layout feels awkward, if the house smells like wet carpet and regret, if the neighbor’s dog has a barking problem, or if the traffic noise sounds like a freeway in the foyer. Use that information when you:
  • Pull recent sales in the neighborhood and break them down by feature. Are homes with pools moving faster than homes with two-car garages? Is a remodeled kitchen getting offers in three days while grandma’s house with shag carpet sits for three months?
  • Look at days on market, sale-to-list ratio, and price-per-square-foot trends. What’s the tipping point for price? What’s the bare minimum upgrade that gets attention?
  • Analyze what actually makes the “sold” column – was it the open floor plan, the quartz countertops, or just the fact that it wasn’t painted beige?

Now take those insights and build a real estate listing presentation that doesn’t just show comps – it translates them into action steps for your sellers. Use Canva to spruce it up.

Tell them:

  • Whether they need to splurge on hardwoods or if fresh carpet will pass the sniff test – literally and figuratively.
  • Whether buyers in their zip code care about curb appeal or just want a good home office.
  • If their 90s bathroom is “vintage charm” or a deal killer in disguise.

And be clear about how you’re going to help them prep. Are you partnering with a company like Curbio or Freemodel to front the reno costs? Will you book the contractor, oversee the install, and babysit the painter? Let them know you’re not just throwing advice at them – you’re managing the whole listing prep like a project boss.

When you walk in with hyper-local insights and a clear listing checklist for getting the house market-ready, you’re not pitching. You’re proving. And that’s exactly how you get listings.

Proven Strategies to Secure Listings (That Don’t Involve Begging Your Aunt’s Hairdresser for a Referral)

Let’s be real: if how to get listings as a real estate agent were as easy as mailing one postcard or boosting a Facebook post, every agent would be buried in listings and sipping LaCroix on their Tuesday afternoon “CEO hour.”

But here’s the truth – real estate listings don’t fall from the sky. You earn them by being visible, credible, and freakishly consistent. Especially in a market where homeowners are bombarded by “I have a buyer for your home” flyers from agents who couldn’t find their own name on the MLS.

So whether you’re brand new and wondering how to get listings as a new real estate agent, or a seasoned pro looking to reboot, these listing strategies are designed to work now – not five years ago when inventory was falling out of the sky.

1. Offer Cash Deals That Flip the Script

Want a shortcut to seller conversations that don’t start with “I’m just curious”? Offer them something no Zestimate ever will: an actual offer.

Cash offer programs (like the ones available through eXp Realty) are gold for sparking interest – and here’s the twist: most sellers don’t take the cash. They take the listing. But that conversation wouldn’t happen without the hook.

  • Mention it in your mailers, ads, and open house flyers.
  • Use it to stand out from other agents who are still pitching “free home evaluations” like it’s 2009.
  • Let sellers know they have options – instant cash or a smarter listing strategy.

It’s a modern strategy for agents who want more real estate listings without begging.

2. Offer a Real Home Valuation (Not a Sad Zestimate Clone)

Everyone and their algorithm offers a home value. But when you show up with a 30-page custom CMA, neighborhood data, buyer trend insights, and a breakdown of ROI upgrades? Now you’re the expert – not the spammy postcard.

This strategy works whether you’re going after expireds, farming, or just trying to get a foot in the door.

  • Promote your free in-depth home valuation across social, your farm, and landing pages.
  • Make a clean QR code that drives people to a simple form (bonus points if it feeds straight into your CRM drip).
  • Use visuals, charts, and real data. Show them their online home value is a guess. Your data is the strategy.

Want more listings? Offer more value than the robots.

3. Turn Open Houses into Listing Traps (The Good Kind)

Most agents treat open houses like a passive hope-fest. You? You’re about to turn them into lead machines.

Before the first looky-loo walks in, hit the pavement:

  • Door knock the neighborhood with a one-page flyer: the home, the recent comps, and your QR code to join your market update email list or request a home valuation.
  • Mention you’re the listing agent in the area, and you’re actively connecting with homeowners about upcoming inventory needs.
  • Ask if they know anyone else thinking of selling – you’ll be surprised who spills the tea.

Spoiler: you’re not just holding an open house – you’re interviewing the block.

4. Rescue Expired Listings with Empathy (and a Game Plan)

Expired listings are the heartbreak kids of the MLS. Someone already wanted to sell – they just didn’t have the right agent (you know, like you).

So what do you do? You listen. Really listen.

  • Come back with a better plan: pro marketing, a pricing refresh, an upgrade strategy, and an actual communication promise.
  • Start with a letter, call, or door knock – then shut up and let them vent.
  • Ask what went wrong. The agent? The pricing? The photos? The lack of follow-up? They’ll tell you – loudly.

If you want to know how to get expired listings in 2025, it starts with empathy, not ego.

5. Target FSBOs (a.k.a. For Sale But Still Very Unsold)

For Sale By Owner listings are like DIY haircuts – usually well-intentioned, sometimes passable, and often in need of professional help by week three.

FSBOs already made one key decision: they want to sell. That’s half the battle. They just don’t yet believe they need you… until their inbox fills with lowballs, scammers, and people asking if “rent-to-own” is an option.

This is where you step in – not with pressure, but with clarity and actual value.

  • Build a FSBO-specific marketing kit with before/after listing photos, staging tips, pricing strategy breakdowns, testimonials, and a sample real estate listing presentation template.
  • Offer easy-entry resources like a detailed CMA, home-selling checklist, or a newsletter that gives them real, actionable steps – without strings attached.
  • Focus on what keeps them up at night: safety, time, liability, and paperwork nightmares. Let them know you’ve got it handled.

Follow up like a human. Consistently – but never pushy. Keep adding value. That way, when they’re finally ready to stop playing listing agent, you’re the first one they call.

6. Implement Geographic Farming (No, Not the Corn Kind)

Want to know how to get more listings in real estate without chasing random leads all over town? Pick a patch and dig in. Hard.

Geographic farming still works – if you do it like a marketer, not a mailman.

  • Choose your farm based on turnover rate, neighborhood growth, and your own market familiarity. This is about smart strategy, not just convenience.
  • Mailers should give real value – like recent real estate listings that sold nearby, equity updates, or seasonal prep tips.
  • Be present offline too: block parties, PTA meetings, school functions. Show up, be helpful, don’t be weird.
  • Double up by hosting open houses for other listings in your farm and door-knocking the block with market data and that same irresistible home valuation offer.

Track everything – mailers, events, ads. You’re not farming for likes; you’re farming for listings. And yes, it takes repetition. Think 11+ touches minimum before someone even thinks about calling you. Stay visible. Stay valuable. Stay consistent.

7. Turn Happy Clients into Walking, Talking Billboards

The cheapest way to get more real estate listings? Stop letting your past clients vanish like they’re in witness protection.

Happy clients are more than just a nice testimonial. They’re your silent sales force – if you give them something to talk about.

  • After closing, deliver a thank-you card with a subtle referral line like, “Now accepting amazing humans you know who need to sell.”
  • Don’t push right away, but circle back later with your latest promo – “If you know someone looking to sell, I’m currently covering seller’s insurance” or whatever you’re offering this month.
  • Schedule an annual equity checkup with a fresh CMA and home update report. Remind them of their home’s value and your value at the same time.
  • Celebrate their home-iversary. Drop by with a coffee or mail a card. Make it personal, not pitchy.

The key? Stay top of mind without being annoying. You’re not a pop-up ad. You’re the helpful friend who always knows what homes are worth.

8. Partner with Divorce Attorneys (The Quiet Goldmine)

If you want to get strategic about how to get listings as a real estate agent, look for professionals who know when someone’s about to sell – before anyone else does.

Enter: divorce attorneys.

  • Start by building connections with local family and estate attorneys. Go to their networking events. Offer coffee, not contracts.
  • Create a seller guide for divorce situations, or co-host a seminar with a legal pro who can walk through timelines and division strategies.
  • Drop off sleek, non-cringey brochures at law offices that outline how you help sellers navigate tense transitions with empathy and results.

This is long game work – but the listings? They’re real, they’re often time-sensitive, and they need a listing agent who knows how to get things done without drama.

9. Host Seller Workshops That Don’t Feel Like Timeshares

Workshops and seminars are the ultimate credibility builder. You get to show off your expertise, earn trust face-to-face, and connect with would-be sellers who haven’t yet raised their hands.

But the key is making it about them, not a weird sales pitch.

  • Teach practical stuff: how to prep a home for sale, how to price smart in today’s market, what buyers actually want right now.
  • Share your listing checklist for getting top dollar – and break down which repairs/upgrades are worth doing.
  • Partner with contractors, stagers, or lenders who can offer value too (just make sure they don’t hijack your spotlight).
  • Capture emails with a sign-in sheet – or better yet, a tablet that feeds right into your CRM and starts an automated drip campaign. (Yes, BoldTrail can do this.)

Workshops not only give sellers clarity – they give you contact info, follow-up permission, and expert status. Total win.

10. Work Your Sphere Like a Pro (Not Like a Desperate Cousin)

Here’s a wild fact: most agents are sitting on a goldmine and don’t even realize it. If someone owns a home, they’re a future seller. Maybe not today – but someday. And if they already know you, that’s half the battle.

You don’t need to be salesy. You just need to be visible, valuable, and slightly less forgettable than their last agent who vanished after closing day.

  • Send handwritten notes, birthday cards, or just a “thinking of you” text that doesn’t start with “just checking in…”
  • Share real value: neighborhood sales updates, home equity estimates, and market trend emails that don’t make people’s eyes glaze over.
  • Host low-key client events like happy hours, backyard BBQs, or coffee shop pop-ins.
  • Schedule a quick “home equity check-in” every year – show them how much they’ve gained and offer a personalized CMA.

This is how you stay top of mind without being that agent. You’re not just building trust – you’re building a listing pipeline that doesn’t rely on strangers or cold calls.

11. Show Up at Local Events (and Talk Like a Human)

Want to know how to get listings as a new real estate agent? Step one: leave the house.

Local events – yes, even the ones with questionable lemonade and school choirs – are where real conversations happen. Because sellers aren’t looking for an agent when they’re ready… they’re looking for one they already know when the time comes.

  • Set up a booth at fairs, festivals, or community yard sales. Offer something simple: a home valuation QR code, a “what’s your home worth?” flyer, or just free bottled water.
  • Volunteer for local causes. Show you care about more than closing deals.
  • Go to events even when you’re not promoting. Chat. Be seen. Be helpful.
  • Collect contact info (nicely). Offer to add them to your monthly newsletter full of local tips, home equity insights, and fun facts – not just boring listings.

Real estate is still a relationship business. So put on your shoes, bring your smile, and maybe a few listing presentations in your trunk – just in case.

12. Partner with Local Businesses (Because Visibility = Trust)

Still wondering how to get more listings in real estate without blowing your budget? Collaborate instead of advertise.

Local businesses are also trying to build trust, get foot traffic, and look like community rockstars. That makes them ideal co-marketing partners.

  • Team up with coffee shops, gyms, bakeries, or salons for giveaways, cross-promotions, or email swaps.
  • Feature one local business in each edition of your seller newsletter or social media series – then ask them to return the favor.
  • Co-host community events like home-selling workshops, market trend nights, or pop-up consult booths during local art walks.

Bonus: These businesses often know before you do who’s thinking about selling. Why? Because sellers vent about their life changes everywhere. Be the agent every business wants to refer.

13. Run Smart Ads That Speak to Sellers

Paid ads don’t have to feel like throwing money into the algorithm void. When done right, online advertising is one of the fastest ways to land real estate listings – especially if you use the right hook.

  • Focus your offer around real value: a no-obligation cash offer, a free 30-page CMA, or a “What’s My Home Worth?” equity report.
  • Run ads on platforms where your potential sellers actually hang out: Facebook, Instagram, Nextdoor, Google, and even LinkedIn.
  • Target by zip code, home value, age, and life stage. A 62-year-old in a 4-bed suburban home? Yeah, they might be open to downsizing.
  • Use video tours, carousel ads, or short punchy clips to grab attention fast.

Track performance weekly. Double down on what’s working. Kill what’s not. You’re not just spending ad dollars – you’re buying attention, seller conversations, and future commissions.

14. Tap Into Pre-Foreclosure Leads (the Right Way)

No, it’s not slimy. Done well, helping people in pre-foreclosure is one of the most ethical and impactful ways to build your business and help your community.

These homeowners are under stress. But they also need options – and most of them have no idea what those options are. Be the person who shows up with empathy and answers.

  • Use tools like PropertyRadar or or follow DistressedPro’s four-step guide to secure foreclosure listings directly from banks.”
  • Offer real solutions: short sales, fast cash offers, or a traditional listing with a timeline they can manage.
  • Build relationships with foreclosure attorneys or financial counselors who can refer clients that are overwhelmed.
  • Provide printed guides or a custom listing checklist for sellers in distress.

Show up not to pitch, but to help. Do that, and you won’t just earn listings – you’ll earn a reputation for being the agent who actually cares.

15. Leverage Social Media (Without Turning Into a Cringe Reels Influencer)

Social media doesn’t need to be a parade of pointing, lip syncing, or dancing (unless that’s your vibe – no judgment). What it does need is relevance, consistency, and a little humanity.

If you’re wondering how do you get listings as a real estate agent in today’s digital world – start here.

  • Post weekly updates about the local market, like “3 homes sold in XYZ neighborhood last week under 7 days.”
  • Share before and after staging photos, sold stats, or a behind-the-scenes look at your listing presentation prep.
  • Get in on neighborhood Facebook groups, local Reddit threads, and Nextdoor conversations.
  • Ask for engagement: “Curious what your home is worth now?” or “Want to see what your neighbor’s home just sold for?”

Stay real, helpful, and just the right amount of visible. Social media isn’t magic. It’s just a modern version of door-knocking – with way better reach.

You Don’t Need Luck – You Need Leverage

There you have it: 15 no-fluff strategies for how to get listings as a real estate agent. Whether you’re chasing expireds, building a referral engine, or running smart ads, the truth is this: listings go to the agents who show up, follow up, and back it all with real strategy. What is a Real Estate Broker (and Brokerage)?

Let’s clear up the identity crisis. In real estate, the words broker and brokerage get tossed around like interchangeable salad toppings – but they’re not the same thing. And when you’re trying to figure out the best real estate brokerage for new agents, knowing the difference actually matters. A lot.

A real estate broker is a licensed pro who’s done the extra credit – more education, a tougher exam – and now has the legal authority to supervise agents or run their own show. They’re the ones who keep deals legal, contracts clean, and agents (mostly) out of trouble. Think of a broker as the designated driver of your real estate transactions.

A real estate brokerage, on the other hand, is a company under which brokers and agents work. The brokerage holds your license and provides your support structure, transaction systems, marketing tools, legal compliance, and—hopefully—some level of actual help.

So, why does this matter to you as a new agent?

Because picking the best real estate broker for new agents isn’t about the logo – it’s about the system behind it. A strong real estate brokerage gives you the training, tools, and support to survive those “what am I doing?” moments. One well-meaning broker can only help so much. The best brokerages offer real structure, real estate training for new agents, and resources that don’t vanish after your first week.

Comparing Brokerage Models

Commission Splits & Fees

We’ll keep this quick – our other blogs go deep on commission math, hidden fees, and how to not feel broke after your first closing. This section is just the essentials.

Commission splits are how your commission gets divided between you and your brokerage. The first number is your cut. So, if you’re on a 60/40 split, you keep 60%, and your brokerage takes 40%. Some brokerages use fixed splits, others use sliding scales that improve as you produce more. A few brokerages offer a cap – once you’ve paid in a set amount (like eXp’s $16K), you keep 100% for the rest of the year.

The tradeoff? Lower splits sometimes come with more support – like leads, training, and tech. Higher splits usually mean you’re more independent (read: figuring things out solo).
